text:
Black Panther has earned a multitude of fans since his record-breaking premiere two week ago, and during last night's episode of The Tonight Show, a few of them took turns recording what they thought were just confessional videos about what the film meant to them. Little did they know, they were actually set up for a surprise from T'Challa himself, Chadwick Boseman.

The fans' messages ranged from funny to sentimental, with many mentioning the significance of seeing a black superhero onscreen. "It's just a great American superhero movie with people who look like me," one man said of the film.

"Basically everything that represents me was honored in this movie," another said.

YouTube

They also thanked Boseman for his performance in the movie.

"My son's childhood has been defined by Barack Obama and now Black Panther," said one mother, who brought her son on set. The young man's face was priceless when the actor emerged from the curtains.

YouTube

"I can't express how much it means to me and the community and my family. Thank you from the bottom of my heart for all that you've done, for really being a hero that we really need in a time like this," said one fan.

He was so shocked when Boseman appeared, he started doing the Wakanda Forever salute.

YouTube

One woman also paid tribute to the black women featured in Black Panther, like Boseman's costars Lupita Nyong'o, Danai Gurira, Angela Bassett, and Letitia Wright.

"They weren't strong because they were angry, they weren't strong because they were hurt, they were strong because they were strong. And that meant the world to me," she said.

Boseman wasn't expecting Black Panther to make this big of an impact. He "knew it would be a revolutionary idea," but he was unsure how the film would be received. "I didn't necessarily know that people would buy out [the seats in] theaters," he told ABC last month.

But they did, and the film grossed over $200 million when it released on President's Day weekend, earning the second-biggest four-day debut ever.
